abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project for Ecuador were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project sustainability was uncertain, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the loan
            supported a particular government's economic reform
            agenda but the closing date was past the end of the
            government's term. In such instances, conditionality
            should be designed to ensure that it will be agreeable to a
            successor government, and should require no difficult or
            controversial actions on the part of the new government.
            This loan illustrated the problems of multi-tranching. In
            single-tranche adjustment operations policy change would be
            implemented before Board approval. The complexity of the
            conditionality was a particular problem when the Bucaram
            government took office. The Bucaram government indicated
            that while it was broadly in accord with the objectives of
            the third-tranche conditionality, it had serious
            reservations about detailed points, which were of lesser
            importance. The Bank, however, had to enforce compliance
            with all the required conditionality, and it proved
            impossible to focus on what was more important.
